contentData.text:
We're not very churchy.

We're relaxed about everything from what we wear to whether the kids can sit still or not.

No-one has to say or do anything that might embarrass them. You are welcome to bring kids of any age.

 

We meet together for about an hour from 4.30-5.30pm. Here is how we spend that time:

We sit round in a circle.

Some of us come 15 mins early to have a chat and a cuppa. At the moment we can chat but no brew and we're socially distancing.

The kids can sit next to you or on the beanbags. We don't mind at all if they make some noise. That's what kids do!

We hear each other's news.

A Christian community is like an extended family. We love each other so we want to hear what's happening in each other's lives. The first 5 minutes or so are for anyone to pipe up with their news.

We sing together.

We love God and so we want to literally sing his praises! They're modern songs, not hymns. Some of them have actions for the kids.
You are welcome to join in (even if you're tone deaf!) or you can just listen.

Someone says sorry to God because we've all messed up.

The good news at the heart of Christianity is that God wants to forgive us. When Jesus died on the cross, he was making it possible for people to be forgiven and accepted by God. We don't want to pretend that we are better than we really are. And it is brilliant to hear every week that there is no sin too shameful, no habit too ingrained and no situation too messy - God can forgive it all!

Then the kids (4-11year olds) go to the room next door while we adults stay where we are.

They play football/games and listen to a story from the Bible. We aim to make Sunday the best day of the week for the kids so we have a lot of fun. And someone always wins the trophy at the end!
For kids younger than 4, they stay in the same room as us adults, and there are toys for them to enjoy and space to run around. We don't expect them to be able to stay still or quiet!

The Bible is read out loud and then explained to us for about 20 minutes

This is how we listen to God. Someone helps us to understand the Bible and how it makes a difference to our lives. They make it interactive, chucking out questions for anyone to answer and asking if anyone's got any questions themselves.

Anyone who wants gets to pray.

The rest of us can say 'Amen' if we want to make the prayer our own.
That's the end of the service. The kids come back to us and anyone who needs to go home, does. Lots of us stay to eat tea together, but not at the moment because of covid.
